content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'accepte

I really like this problem, but not that much for a Clash.
For me, in a Clash, I don't like to spend that much time reading and trying to figure out what is being asked, but jump as quick as possible into thinking how to solve it.
I feel that part of the appeal of the problem is identify that you don't actually have to implement radix sort, but I would rather see this as an easy problem or have the description reduced to something like below:

"Statement
Radix sort is an algorithm that, after K passes, sorts numbers by their last K digits.
Given an initial sequence of N numbers and the number of passes K, what will the sequence look like?

Rules:
Numbers are compared digit-by-digit from right to left, up to K digits.
Numbers with fewer than K digits are padded with leading zeros.
When numbers have the same last K digits, they maintain their original relative order."
Interesting. So the task is equivalent to sorting number base solely on the K last digits?

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: je la tourve exelent

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I‚Äôve reviewed your contribution and I‚Äôm happy to accept it. The problem is well-designed, clearly explained, and the test cases are solid. Great work ‚Äî thanks for submitting it!

Great job on this Clash of Code contribution! The concept is clever, the test cases are well-designed, and the problem really highlights a solid understanding of Radix Sort. It‚Äôs both challenging and fair ‚Äî exactly the kind of puzzle that makes the platform fun. Really impressive work!‚Äù

Interesting puzzle.
I think it might be too complicated for a clash.

Additionally, in your testcase "Integer Limit" (and later ones) you have some numbers that are not integers in a programming sense, e.g. 8610699812119. That is an integer in a mathematical sense, but not parsable as an int. This might cause some confusion, since you specify in your constraints that "Each number in the sequence is a non-negative integer."

Imho the task is not very suitable for a 1-2 minute solution in a ClashOfCode. The task description is not very clear. In particular, it could be written that i varies from 1 to the number of digits of the maximum number.
Thank you for your feedback! I've updated the description accordingly. Let me know if there's anything else I should change.
Thank you for your feedback! Yes, those large numbers are not meant to be parsed into integers. I specified the limit of these large numbers via the constraint 0 < D ‚â§ 100.
That and the initial relative order of the numbers, yes :)

Hey @Tecnokinema, thanks for the feedback! I agree that the reading part of this clash is quite cumbersome. And I quite like your shortened statement! The only issue would be that the problem loses the context of radix sort entirely.

Do you think I should remove the notion of radix sort entirely or try to incorporate some element of it in the problem statement?

Yeah, I agree, the radix sort part makes the problem more interesting!
If it were me, I would keep the problem as-is, but just not for a Clash, instead as a regular puzzle.
But if the goal is to have it as a Clash, as a "problem solver", I wouldn't like to be chasing red herrings. That is, I wouldn't like to have to be thinking on buckets and everything needed for a radix sort, when it's likely I won't be implementing it to solve the problem.
(Sorry if this doesn't actually answer your question directly üòÖ)

Got it! Here's what I think I will do:

- For this clash, I will remove the extended description and replace it with your shortened description.

- I will craft a separate Easy puzzle that will use my current description but require more of the player; e.g., forcing them to output the ASCII bucket view at a certain iteration of the radix sort.
I've edited the clash description! Do let me know if it's ok.

Yeah, seems pretty good to me!
(Would approve it, but seems it has already been accepted üòÖ)

No worries, your verbal approval is just as valuable.

Thank you for the feedback!
Nice idea, I really like it. My only concern is that this equivalence is not completely obvious and writing the entire iterative radix sort may take a some time.

I think the time it takes to write the iterative radix sort depends largely on the language of choice by each clasher. More importantly, however, I would hope that clashers would be able to derive the task equivalent :)

The task looks daunting (though it really isn't). Would it be better to ask players to sort the numbers **only once** based on a specified position? (Your original intention might be for the player to figure out the shortcut method, as shown in your solution, but‚Ä¶) This approach would simplify both the explanation and the illustrative example. For instance, players could be asked to sort the numbers by the 1st digit only, or by the 4th digit only, without introducing the concept of buckets.

Regardless of the above suggestion, the statement should specify what to do when a number doesn't have a digit in that position (e.g. treat the missing digit as 0).

If you intend to retain the original multi-iteration task, the statement should explicitly clarify that the sorted sequence of each iteration serves as the input for the next iteration. Also, the phrase "concatenating the buckets" may sound a bit abstract for some readers. You might consider using simpler and clearer wording.

Using point form to list the steps could also help.

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback! I've listed the radix sort instructions in point form and made the example more explicit.

I don't particularly like the concept of "sorting by the nth digit only" because I think it takes away from learning about radix sort. The shortcut method isn't meant to be the "intended" method, but it's just the way I approached this problem.

Thanks. It's looking better.

I get why you set up the task the way it is. I think the description could maybe be simplified a bit more, but others might be fine with it as is. Let's see what they think first.

Close to impossible in reverse mode, but seems great to me for fastest and (especially) shortest CoC. It should be doable in ~5 minutes, even without prior knowledge on the radix algorithm.

This is a very nice puzzle!
@RobbertvZ yep i concur with you on the difficulty of Reverse mode, which is why I didn't enable it for this clash. Thank you for the feedback!
